title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Turn R data pipelines scalable collaborative network graph.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: xafty turns data pipeline dependency graph instead linear script. step becomes reusable node declares needs provides. xafty resolves execution order , enables reuse across projects, hides complexity behind clean layers abstraction.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: data pipelines built one-scripts: hard reuse, fragile change, difficult teams collaborate . projects grow, leads duplicated logic, inconsistent results, constant need rebuild work already exists. xafty solves treating every transformation reusable node shared dependency graph. Instead rewriting steps every new project, teams compose pipelines existing, validated building blocks. makes data work reliable, maintainable, far easier extend time.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: High flexibility overhead: Since node just function data.frame → data.frame, don’t adopt new data model rewrite existing logic. Existing code drops directly network minimal changes. Reduced cognitive burden: don’t need remember correct sequence function calls. Colleagues don’t need study pipeline figure get data need. simply query variables, xafty evaluates required steps. deciding variables needs, writing function takes returns data.frame, registering network. Effortless collaboration: Networks invite contribution. Dropping new node simple low-risk, unlike pipelines every change risks breaking flow.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Let’s understand idea behind xafty going step step simple script network pipeline. Step 1: “Stateful” pipeline Step 2: Functional pipeline Step 3: Network pipeline

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Probably everyone starting data analytics written data pipeline looked similar following: good start. gets point, fast comprehensible. codebase use-cases grow, several problems emerge: Hard reuse: Scripts linear stateful. colleague want part logic, need copy-paste code manually recreate upstream context. often breaks steps depend hidden side effects object states. Difficult scale: script grows, earlier steps become tightly coupled later ones. Small changes upstream can unintentionally cascade downstream, making pipeline fragile harder extend. Locked one use-case: linear script encodes single way run pipeline. later need different subsets data, alternative derivations, multiple outputs, entire script must restructured duplicated.
code: # 1. Load data data("mtcars")  # 2. Add derived variable mtcars$power_to_weight <- mtcars$hp / mtcars$wt  # 3. Get engine lookup table engine <- data.frame(   type = as.factor(c("Straight", "V-Shape")),   vs = c(1, 0) )  # 4. Join everything together mtcars <- merge(mtcars, engine, by = "vs", all.x = TRUE, sort = FALSE)  # 5. Use results plot(mtcars$type, mtcars$power_to_weight)

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: can address many shortcomings “stateful” script, writing everything function: already major improvement. modular structure makes pipeline composable, testable, reusable, much easier understand. approach modularizes logic, still needs assembled manually: Implicit dependency chains: function still relies called correct order. Dependencies remain implicit code flow, pipeline can break someone rearranges reuses functions without fully understanding upstream assumptions. Limited flexibility different outputs: need return slightly different subset data, produce multiple alternative outputs, end copying, commenting branching functions. pipeline becomes tangle custom assembly code instead reusable structure. Difficult reason impact: function modified, built-way ask: parts pipeline rely ? might change affect? Understanding ripple effects becomes manual error-prone process.
code: get_mtcars <- function() {   data("mtcars", envir = environment())   mtcars }  add_power_to_weight <- function(mtcars) {   mtcars$power_to_weight <- mtcars$hp / mtcars$wt   mtcars }  get_engine_details <- function() {   engine <- data.frame(     type = as.factor(c("Straight", "V-Shape")),     vs = c(1, 0)   )   engine }  join_engine_details <- function(mtcars, engine) {   joined <- merge(mtcars, engine, all.x = TRUE, sort = FALSE)   joined }  plot_mtcars <- function(mtcars) {  mtcars_plot <- plot(mtcars$type, mtcars$power_to_weight)  mtcars_plot }  # Assemble the pipeline mtcars_plot <- function() {  mtcars <- get_mtcars()  engine <- get_engine_details()    mtcars <- join_engine_details(mtcars = mtcars, engine = engine)  mtcars <- add_power_to_weight(mtcars = mtcars)    plot_mtcars(mtcars = mtcars) }  # Run the pipeline mtcars_plot()

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Moving functional pipeline network pipeline final step making code fully declarative, flexible, scalable. logic Step 2 looks expressed xafty network: xafty, function Step 2 becomes node network. query() calls declare variables needed inputs. Using declarations, xafty builds dependency graph knows: needs computed, order, data sources. call nascent(), xafty walks graph, resolves nodes required request, evaluates topological order, returns precisely asked . Pipelines longer assembled manually. simply query data need let system orchestration.
code: ## Preparation:  # Make sure that the functions from Step 2 are loaded into memory. ## /Preparation  library(xafty)  # Initialize the network with the desired structure xafty_network <- init_network("example_network", projects = c("mtcars", "engine"))  ## Register the functions in project "mtcars" ##  # The function `get_mtcars()` is registered as a root node in the project "mtcars". xafty_network$mtcars$get(get_mtcars())  # Instead of passing data to `add_power_to_weight`, we register a dependency using query() xafty_network$mtcars$add(add_power_to_weight(mtcars = query(mtcars = c("hp", "wt"))))  ## Register the functions in project "engine" ##  xafty_network$engine$get(get_engine_details())  # Here we register a join, by passing two separate queries to the according parameters xafty_network$mtcars$join(join_engine_details(mtcars = query(mtcars = "vs"),                                               engine = query(engine = "vs")))  # Inspect the network xafty_network  # Pull data as needed from the network xafty_network |> nascent(mtcars = c("hp", "wt", "vs"), engine = "type", mtcars = "power_to_weight")  # We can also add the plot to the network as a finished data product xafty_network$mtcars$add_object("mtcars_plot",                                  plot_mtcars(mtcars = query(engine = "type", mtcars = "power_to_weight")))  # To query an object from the network, write the object's name in squared brackets xafty_network |> nascent(mtcars = "[mtcars_plot]")

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: xafty still active development, find already quite feature rich: Stateful programming states, passed alongside queries via with_state(). Context entry/exit project, similar dplyr::group_by() / ungroup(), enabling wrapping lossless transformations. Wildcard selection query(project = "*") request variables project. Inspection tools, xafty::build_dag(), view internal dependency graph.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Network-based pipelines open door many extensions integrations. overview near-term roadmap ambitious directions.

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Version 1.0 aims make xafty practical solution ~95% everyday data-pipeline workflows. reach milestone, several essential features still need implemented: Support lossy transformations (e.g., dplyr::group_by() / summarise()), integrated seamlessly network structure flexible filtering mechanism using () clause, providing fine-grained control filtering applied Developer tooling, visualizations printable summaries network components, make building xafty easier Robust testing bug fixing ensure reliability scale

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: Beyond core roadmap, xafty can evolve powerful component within existing analytic ecosystems: Integration {targets}: DAG created via xafty::build_dag() translated directly {targets} pipeline, unlocking caching, parallel processing, full reproducibility Interoperability DuckDB Arrow: Allowing nodes backed SQL Python enable cross-language collaboration high-performance hybrid networks

title: Build Scalable Data Pipelines
text: xafty active development, feedback incredibly valuable! ’re curious, testing , ideas improve , want prioritize feature get touch open issue. Whether ’s bugs, feature requests, just chat, ’d love hear ! :)

title: Set or Change the Print Order of Projects — set_project_print_order
code: xafty_network <- init_network("change_order",                    projects = c("Project2", "Project1")) print(xafty_network) # Prints Project2 first, then Project1 #> Number of projects in network 'change_order': 2 #>  #> Project: Project2 #>  #> Project: Project1  # Change the print order set_project_print_order(   projects = c("Project2", "Project1"),   order = c(2, 1),   network = xafty_network ) print(xafty_network) #> Number of projects in network 'change_order': 2 #>  #> Project: Project1 #>  #> Project: Project2
